PM

BE

RBC ......

BE

Our view: Forecasts reduced by ~10% throughout our forecast horizon on
lower revenue per client. We cut our price target to 320p from 335p. CMC
remains a coiled spring that awaits the return of market volatility, and we
therefore maintain our Outperform rating even though sentiment in the
near term is likely to become negative.

11:11 am
PM

Ha

BE

CMC issued a trading update ahead of its AGM which indicates that for
the five month period to 31-Aug, active clients are up 9% compared to the
same period last year. Further, client money balances at the end of August
are 21% higher than at the same point last year, and we believe that client
money indicates a client’s propensity to trade and is a positive indicator
of future growth potential. However, low levels of volatility are resulting
in lower revenue per client, and despite a higher number of clients, Net
Operating Income for the six months to 30-Sep is expected to be lower
than the same period last year. CMC is “confident” that Net Operating
Income will improve in the second half because of its larger funded client
base, growing institutional offering and new product development. The
company adds that there “continues to be a focus on cost control.”
The key changes that we make are to reduce FY17 revenue per client
growth to -5% from +2%, and to reduce FY17 active client growth to +10%
from +11%. We make no other material changes to our forecasts. The
result is to decrease our EPS forecasts by 9%, 11% and 8% in FY17E, FY18E
and FY19E, respectively.

BE

Price target decreased 15p, or 4%, to 320p. We roll-forward our valuation
and we now value CMC at 14x (previous: 15x) our CY18 EPS forecast
(previous: CY17), in line with our IG valuation (however we value IG at
15x CY18 EPS). We continue to incorporate CMC’s surplus capital in our
valuation. Our price target is negatively impacted by lower forecasts,
which is somewhat offset by rolling forward our valuation to use our
CY18 EPS forecast, albeit at a lower multiple.
We believe the nature of today’s statement is market-related – and
not company-related. Nonetheless, we fully acknowledge that today’s
statement is a ding to the confidence of management just seven months
after the company’s IPO. However, this is a bump in the road – not a
detour; we do not believe that this is the start of a downgrade cycle.
The shares are likely to overreact (on the downside), and then investors
will realise that an investment in CMC still yields exposure to growth,
returns and a very favourable valuation comparison to its closet peer. CMC
remains a coiled spring that awaits the return of market volatility, and we
therefore maintain our Outperform rating even though sentiment in the
near term is likely to become negative.

11:11 am
PM

CMC remains a coiled spring that awaits the return of market volatility,

PM

Wot?

BE

And Goldman, which I assume was also on the float ticket. Because Goldman.

11:12 am
BE

News
CMC Markets released a trading statement this morning (September 7th) to
coincide with the group’s AGM later today. While CMC has continued to
add new customers and cash balances, overall activity levels have been
subdued over the summer months. While our forecasts were for 10% yoy
revenue growth in FY 1H17, management now anticipates a yoy decline.
We expect this to have a negative impact on the group’s shares.
Analysis
CMC reported growth of 9% in active customers in the five months to the
end of August. While this represents a modest deceleration from the 13%
growth seen in calendar 2Q16, it implies that CMC continues to rapidly
expand its customer base. A19% yoy increase in new customers also
suggests that CMC continues to offer an attractive customer proposition.
Subdued volatility in July and August, however, has adversely impacted
the amount of trading these clients undertake. As a result, management
expects first-half revenues to be lower than last year’s figure of £78.9 mn.
By implication, the group’s FY 1H17 revenues will be at least 10% lower
than our £86.7 mn forecast. The low proportion of variable costs is likely to
further amplify the impact on the group’s first-half profits.
Management is also “confident” that revenues “will improve in the second
half”. This partly reflects the seasonality inherent in CMC’s revenues, but it
also recognises the underlying growth of CMC’s business. For example, the
amount of money clients held available for trading purposes was 21%
higher yoy at the end of August.
Implications
Despite the recent slowdown in revenue growth, CMC’s management still
expects to achieve its 2020 revenue target of £220 mn.
We place our forecasts, price target and investment recommendation
under review pending further analysis.

BE

Note this is post a July 21 trading statement as well, which flagged up ‘moderate’
weakening in revenue-per-customer over calendar 2Q16

BE

But had apparently bounced back post Brexit.

BE

At the management level Mr Forsey had failed to inform the Board (or Mr Ashley) ofsome of the issues namely the progress of the NMW issue in a timely or effective manner over the course of a year or so. Warning signs that had been given off by the media and to a lesser extent the Unions regarding NMW issues had not been heeded properly or adequately and so some points were not escalated.
As CEO Mr Forsey openly acknowledges that he is ultimately responsible for the day to day running of the company and should have insisted on a stronger warehouse management structure, clearer responsibilities between SDI and the Agency management teams and better direct communication between HR and the Board. Consequently Mr Forsey was requested to forego his share bonus entitlement worth in the region of £3.6m (at that time) in recognition of the shortcomings.

BE

In the FY15 directors’ remuneration report, we reported that all the performance conditions for Dave Forsey’s award over 1m shares granted in August 2011 under the Executive Share Scheme had been met, and the value of those shares was included in the single figure table for FY15. Vesting of those shares was deferred until 2017. On 6 June 2016 the Company and the Committee were informed of the decision of Dave Forsey to forego the vesting of these shares. At the time of the announcement this represented a value of approximately £3.6m. The Committee believe that this is very much reflective of the Executive Directors sharing risk with shareholders and taking responsibility for results that fell short of their expectation.

The shares have been very strong in recent days on improved sentiment due to SPD’s own review of its working practices, including the appointment of a worker’s representative to its board, so we expect the shares to give back some of this due to its lower profit guidance.
Our FY18 EBITDA forecast is 14% below consensus given cost and currency pressures and as we think it will be challenging for SPD to raise prices when consumer disposable incomes are being squeezed. We maintain our Underperform rating on the shares.

11:25 am
BE

And Jefferies ....

BE

Conclusions: SPD's strategic update today will likely put the stock on the back-foot with
c.dd% cuts to consensus EPS. SPD has outlined a major step-up in property investments,
and with it a likely sharp deterioration in leverage. Some of the more controversial aspects
of governance remain a point of conflict (with the property function leadership confirmed
and US$ hedging policy remaining non-existent).

Details: SPD sees EBITDA fall by over 20% in 16/17 to c.£300m vs cons of £307m. This is
underpinned by sales of at least +9% (we expect strongly boosted by weaker £/€), gross
margins to contract by no more than 275bps and cost growth of max 8%. EPS mismatch
will be exacerbated by a major step up in property investments (£250m invested since the
start of the year, with another £300m to come) leading to depreciation spiking to £120m
this year (vs cons of £100m). At this stage, there are few details on trading performance YTD
or a more comprehensive discussion around capital structure.

11:26 am
PM

Let me get

PM

We are happy to stick with this after turning buyer yesterday and view the 10% slide as an opportunity. This is clearly not for all, but anyone who witnessed the PlayTech saga of a few years ago (46M share placing to founder at 215p in November 2011, shares now trading at around 900p), we think this might play out in similar fashion. When you have a single owner in control of more than 50%, as you do here, governance issues get exacerbated given the lack of control minorities have to enact change. But there seems change is afoot here (see note from yesterday), and while the operational figures have disappointed, again, we view things as approaching some form of a trough. If we are correct (and a rally in sterling would certainly help margins) our thesis is thus: before investments, Sports Direct is generating 10% of its market cap in cash with which it is building market share across Europe with a vertically integrated low cost model. Using a normalised net margin of 6.5% on a £3.0B top line we see fair value in the mid-500s vs a current price of under 320p/share at present. Further share buybacks and mid-single digit top-line growth (pre-M&A) mean earnings can still compound, making for a very high IRR once a fairer multiple based on the earnings power of the franchise is once again regained. As we say, not for all. Some will simply not invest given the lack of (minority) control. But for those that can, we think it could be interesting. Buy Sports Direct *.

PM

Brave call.

11:01 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

We argue that the ongoing strength of Sports Direct's unique product mix, an immature online operation and further organic expansion into Europe underpin the group's sales growth forecast. Combined with long-term margin expansion opportunity, this drives our Buy rating on the shares. Although the forecast agenda drives limited earnings growth, with the shares are trading at c.8.5x EV/EBIT for FY18e (on consensus estimates), we view this as a compelling entry point.

BE

Sports Direct really is an indictment of the City, isn't it?

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 550.00, down 19.5 (-3.42%), High: 571.00, Low: 539.50, Volume: 2.25m

BE

BE

11:36 am
BE

I mean, deliberately. They don't sell them and say they're chicken.

BE

BE

Benares, also, is pretty high end. They're clearly going for whatever differentiation they can.

11:38 am
BE

I guess we're going to have to quote Northern Trust again, aren't we? Because Neil Campling's the go-to chap on J sell .

BE

Just Eat bulls will likely claim that the delivery network model doesn’t provide favourable economics, but then Amazon (like Uber) care about land grab and quick scale not quick economic returns. Just Eat will likely argue that the last mile logistics piece is too difficult to offer and the business model was more focused on moving an inefficient existing order execution market online. But the risks are rising in our view that Just Eat will have to consider the same. Competition from the likes of Amazon, UberEATS, Deliveroo, Delivery Hero et al will suppress returns on capital for all entrants. The allure of high growth of the industry (due to the channel shift towards online ordering) is behind the rise of new entrants. The bullish thesis on Just Eat is a perception that Amazon will have little impact on Just Eat as their focus is on the restaurant delivery market in London rather than, say, delivering a kebab in Barnsley on a Tuesday night. Time will tell…. But Amazon doesn’t do small scale over time – and nor does Uber.

BE

Can Just Eat force through higher commission rates, lower marketing spend, and significantly higher margins in the face of intensifying competition? And Amazon Flex, for example, could prove to be a secret weapon. Amazon can reduce the cost per delivery by bundling deliveries from multiple restaurants to similar locations and improve service by accelerating delivery time. The Flex network reduces the network latency and inefficiency bottlenecks. Flexible workers sign up for a block of time and then get allocated metro areas and services (including Amazon packages, Prime NOW and pickups from restaurants and stores). Amazon Flex is now in 24 areas in the US and is beginning to expand in the UK.

We expect Just Eat’s planned path to maintaining high growth while pushing through higher commission rates will be challenged, and their need to defend mind and market share as UK competition intensifies this year will likely pressure EBITDA margins. We remain sellers of JE/ LN.

11:40 am
BE

(@A.M: I'm thinking there probably is, though at the Ramsay-level I'm sure it's manageable.)

BE

Oh, and as I reach for any possible counterpoint, I note that Jefferies has gotten round to writing about Takeaway.com's IPO yesterday.

BE

Takeaway.com's intention to float statement, good for Just Eat, in our opinion. CEO Groen another excellent operator and he has built a strong Benelux business. Germany remains profoundly loss-making and perhaps is a competitive 'bloodbath'. We sense the IPO accelerates European consolidation.

11:42 am
BE

"remains profoundly loss-making and perhaps is a competitive 'bloodbath'"! Where to I sign up?!

BE

Perhaps three key talking points for investors:

Germany, a material market for Takeaway.com, one in which the company is committed to a positive EBITDA margin 'within the next two or three years'. The FT wrote yesterday about the 'bloodbath' competitive dynamic in Germany; two very capable market participants, Takeaway.com and Delivery Hero slugging it out. Who will win and at what price?
All things 'last mile', we've 'done' that debate, but inevitably the threats supposedly facing Just Eat will be wheeled out for Takeaway.com. It seems that in the Netherlands at least, the restaurant network remains attached to delivery and the competitive threat from Deliveroo et al manageable...
And inevitably valuation... a comparison to Just Eat obvious and we like Just Eat's 15/18 earnings CAGR, c. +58% for 25x '18 adjusted EPS. Given Takeaway.com's profitability it seems that EBITDA and earnings metrics will not be relevant, EV/Sales anyone?

BE

And in conclusion. Fundamentally think the Takeaway.com IPO is good for Just Eat, brings another peer public and one that is probably more relevant than Grubhub, enabling a fuller valuation debate as investors explore how growth profile and valuation rating compares. It may be that the public markets pricing Takeaway.com accelerates consolidation in the sector also. A Hungry House deal surely now more likely as a result of the Takeaway.com IPO.

11:43 am
BE

(@Chad: I was surprised too, but Atul's a clever chap who I'm sure knows what he's doing. I'd not be surprised if deliveries are restricted to a half mile of Mayfair only.)

Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 497.50, down 9.5 (-1.87%), High: 522.50, Low: 494.00, Volume: 3.26m
BE

11:51 am
BE

Here's Credit Suisse.

BE

Following a solid set of FY16 results and positive commentary on current
trading conditions post the EU Referendum, we raise our FY17/18 EPS by
an average 14% and increase our TP to 464p (from 426p). However, owing
to the strong rally in Barratt share price our new TP corresponds to a
Neutral rating which we therefore maintain.
Solid results: Following a relatively comprehensive trading update in July,
where FY16 revenue, PBT and year end net cash position were disclosed this
morning's results contained few numerical surprises. Barratt confirm FY16 sales
grew 13% to £4.2bn and Group delivered PBT of £682m +13% YoY, ending the
year with a net cash position of £592m (vs. £187m FY15).

BE

Positive current trading: net private sales reservations per active site per week
were reported up 6% YoY from the period from 1st July and the total forward
order book currently stands at £2.42bn, +4% YoY. The Group goes on to state
"Our sales trends since the start of the new financial year have been
encouraging, and underpin an increasingly ‘business-as-usual’ stance". On
London however, management state sales rate above £600k continue to slow.

11:51 am
BE

FY17 guidance and capital special dividend maintained: We note no
changes have been made to FY17 target to deliver at least a 20% gross margin
and 25% ROCE. Additionally, management confirmed it's intension to return
£175m in special dividends in FY17, following the issuance of £125m (12.4p/sh)
special dividends in FY16. Total FY16 DPS (spec+ord) is 30.7p/share.
Increase FY17/18 EPS forecasts: in light of the positive current trading
trajectory reported post the EU Referendum, we raise our FY17/18 EPS by an
average 14% reflecting our more positive view on Group volume, ASP and
margin progression.

BE

And Canaccord, saying the same pretty much.

BE

Barratt has delivered a set of results consistent with its recent trading update. There
are no surprises in the results reported with PBT of £682m slightly better than our
forecast of £680m (+c.21%). The group invested heavily in land during the financial year
to June 2016, with 24,387 plots approved for purchase. The balance sheet is strong
with net cash of £592m as expected, but better than had been guided earlier this year.
Comments on recent trading are reassuring and consistent with what others in the
sector have recently reported. The group has seen a positive start to the new financial
year with net private reservations per outlet per week since 1st July up at 0.75 versus
0.71 last year. Total capital return including the special dividend was 30.7p as expected.
Management is taking a business as usual approach, while monitoring the market
closely, and expects a modest increase in completions during the current financial year.
Consensus remains a wide range, but if current positive trends continue through the
autumn selling season we believe the lower end of the range is likely to move to a less
bearish expectation. Shares have enjoyed a relief rally recently along with the sector, as
news on recent trading has been relatively positive, and now reside on a 2017E P/NAV
multiple of c.1.6 times.

PM

Just on the Sports Direct AGM

PM

On the corporate governance theme...

11:59 am
PM

Mr. Chairman, members of the board of Sports Direct International. My name is Euan Stirling and I am Head of Stewardship and Environmental, Social and Governance Investment at Standard Life Investments. On behalf of our clients, we own 34 million shares in Sports Direct International, representing 5.8% of the issued share capital.

Today, we have voted against the company’s remuneration report and against the reappointment of all of the non-executive directors. I would like to explain why we have adopted this approach and taken such a strong stance in opposition to the board’s recommendations.

We are longstanding shareholders in the company and have engaged with senior executives and non-executives over many years, sadly to little effect. The responses to our enquiries have been either unconvincing or non-existent. In that context, yesterday’s RPC report into working practices represents a positive step forward.

By contrast, we do appreciate the scale and the market position of the business and its long-term value creation potential. That is why we remain fully-engaged shareholders.

In order to achieve that potential, we increasingly believe that a structural change in the way that the company is governed is now required. In speaking to the select committee of the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills this year, Mr Ashley acknowledged as much himself, referring to the way that the business has grown in both size and complexity.

PM

Tight cost control can be an attractive feature of a business. However, taken too far, and with a focus on the short-term, it can and does result in the starvation of investment in talent, facilities and infrastructure which can leave a business vulnerable to its competitors and its own weaknesses.

In order for the company’s equity value to reflect its potential, we encourage the board to bold action. We would like to see Mr Ashley with a role, title and responsibilities that reflect his influence as majority shareholder and founder of the business.

And we would like to see that pivotal role supported, as well as challenged, by a group of talented and experienced executives. It is our opinion that even then, substantial strengthening of the non-executive members of the board will be required, particularly in the crucial role of Chairman.

We welcome yesterday’s publication of the Working Practices Report and the positive change that is likely to bring to some of Sports Directs workers. However, the ‘Follow up’ commitment noted in Section 1.5 of the report is insufficient to realise the group’s full potential.

In order to arrive at the correct structural conclusions, we believe that a full and independent review of governance at the company is required, along with a commitment to publish and act on the review’s conclusions and recommendations in the next twelve months.

We would like to ask the board to commit to this course of action in order to achieve the associated objectives of structural change and long-term value creation.

PM

BE

Which someone on the right requested. I forget who.

BE

Ahead of its AGM, Vectura has announced raised revenue guidance for 2016. Whilst no specific guidance had previously been given, Vectura now expects revenues for 2016 to be ahead of previous expectations. In addition to strong sales growth of Ultibro and flutiform which have driven growth in royalty income, sales of legacy products Solaraze and Advate have also benefited from one-off factors boosting royalties. We currently forecast pro forma revenues of £175m in 2016. On our forecasts, Vectura currently trades on a 2017 P/E of 14.4x, a significant discount to its peers. Reiterate Buy.

BE

Core respiratory products continue to drive growth: As reported on 30
August 2016, flutiform in-market net sales for the six month period to June
2016 were 42% ahead YoY at €92.4m (1H15 €65.1m). It is now launched in 31
countries, approved in nine others, and under review for approval in 15 other
countries. Ultibro continues to perform strongly - in July 2016 Novartis reported
total net sales for Ultibro of $100m in 2Q16, up 52% on 2Q15 ($66m). Seebri
sales of $39m represented a 3% YoY increase (2Q15 $38m). Novartis plans to
update the market on its launch strategy for Utibron and Seebri in the US in
3Q16 – at present Vectura believes they will be launched in 2H16, especially
in light of the continued positive sales momentum and results from the FLAME
study published at the 2016 European Respiratory Society International
Congress this week

12:04 pm
BE

Pipeline review: Vectura also announced a pipeline update following a review
of the combined companies. As a result, the company expects to develop
between three and five new generic inhalation assets largely funded by
partners. It has also selected VR588, a novel broad-based selective pan-JAK
inhibitor as an inhaled therapy, to progress into Phase I/IIa planning (having
previously been in preclinical studies), which is also likely to be partnered in
future. SKP-2075, a low-dose theophylline-ICS combination in development for
COPD, has been put on hold following the staff consultation process that
formed part of the merger. The c.£15m R&D spend which had been assigned
to SKP-2075 will now provide funding for the other development programmes,
and the board’s R&D expectations therefore remain unchanged for 2016 and
2017.
Reiterate Buy rating. Based on our current forecasts Vectura trades on a
2017 P/E of 14.4x. We believe recent share price weakness has been
overdone. Buy.
